title: Healing Plants: 3 Safe & Effective Ways to Use Plants as Medicine
author: Lisa Bryant; ND
description: People have been using plants as medicine for as long as humans have walked the earth. While there's a prescription drug for just about everything nowadays, plants have a lot to offer if you prefer a more natural approach to your health...
cleaned_text: This article was co-authored by [Lisa Bryant, ND](/Experts?name=lisabryant%2Cnd#lisabryant%2Cnd). Dr. Lisa Bryant is Licensed Naturopathic Physician and natural medicine expert based in Portland, Oregon. She earned a Doctorate of Naturopathic Medicine from the National College of Natural Medicine in Portland, Oregon and completed her residency in Naturopathic Family Medicine there in 2014. There are [18 references](#References) cited in this article, which can be found at the bottom of the page. This article has been viewed 2,535 times. People have been using plants as medicine for as long as humans have walked the earth. While there's a prescription drug for just about everything nowadays, plants have a lot to offer if you prefer a more natural approach to your health care. You can take medicinal plants and herbs in pill form, cook with them, or apply them to your skin to help treat various conditions. Just be sure to talk to your doctor before starting any new supplements or diet regimen, and make sure you buy your plant-based supplements from reputable stores and manufacturers. Steps Taking Plant-Based Supplements - 1Boost your immune system with echinacea. Echinacea is commonly believed to prevent or treat colds, flu, and upper respiratory infections. If you're already sick, taking a supplement or sipping on echinacea tea can shorten the duration of your illness. Just keep in mind that it's not a cure-all and it's still important to get enough rest and eat nutritious foods to overcome your illness. [[1]](#_note-1)X [Trustworthy Source](/wikiHow:Delivering-a-Trustworthy-Experience)PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health [Go to source](#) - Do not take echinacea if you are allergic to plants in the daisy family (like ragweed, chrysanthemums, marigolds, and daisies). - Echinacea is available in a variety of forms, including capsules, tinctures, and teas. - Most echinacea supplements should be taken 3 times daily, and the dosage varies based on the form of the supplement (e.g., .25-1.25 mL of liquid extract per dose, or 1-2 mL of the tincture). [[2]](#_note-2)X Research source [Follow the directions on the package or consult a naturopathic specialist to determine the right dose for you.](#) - 2Use ginkgo biloba for a healthy brain. This plant can improve your memory and help prevent dementia and other brain disorders. You can take ginkgo in pill form or drink ginkgo tea. Take anywhere from 120 mg to 160 mg per day, starting at 120 mg and working your way up if you feel the need. [[3]](#_note-3)X [Trustworthy Source](/wikiHow:Delivering-a-Trustworthy-Experience)PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health [Go to source](#) - Only use extracts from ginkgo leaves, as the seeds of the plant are toxic. - Ginkgo biloba slows blood clotting, so don't take it with anticoagulants like warfarin, aspirin, ibuprofen, and other antiplatelet drugs. - 3Keep your liver healthy with milk thistle. Milk thistle can help ease inflammation of the liver and promote cellular repair. However, studies are mixed as to how effective it is in treating viral or alcoholic liver cirrhosis. Drink milk thistle tea (up to 3 cups per day) or take it as a supplement. The recommended dosage for treating liver disease is 200 to 400 mg per day. [[4]](#_note-4)X [Trustworthy Source](/wikiHow:Delivering-a-Trustworthy-Experience)PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health [Go to source](#) - Potential side effects that make it a less-enticing treatment option for liver conditions include nausea, diarrhea, skin reactions, rhinoconjunctivitis, impotence, headaches, insomnia, and anaphylaxis. However, these side effects are rare. - Always talk to you doctor and/or gastroenterologist before using milk thistle to treat liver disease. - 4Regulate blood sugar and lower cholesterol with psyllium husk. Psyllium husk is a form of fiber made from the seeds of the blond plantain plant (plantago ovata). While it's commonly known to have laxative properties, it's also a prebiotic, helping people with diabetes maintain a healthy balance of glucose and insulin. Studies have shown that taking psyllium husk lowers LDL cholesterol, especially in people who have type 2 diabetes. [[5]](#_note-5)X Research source - The recommended dosage is 5.1 grams of psyllium twice a day. Talk to your doctor about finding the right dosage for you. - 5Relieve depression naturally with St. John's Wort. Various studies have shown that St. John's Wort is just as effective in treating mild to moderate depression as common antidepressants. It's a good option if you suffer from mild depression and want a natural alternative to prescription drugs. The recommended dose is 250 mg 2 times a day. [[6]](#_note-6)X Research source - Do not take St. John's Wort if you are taking antidepressants because this could lead to a potentially life-threatening condition called "serotonin syndrome." - St. John's Wort can affect the efficacy of birth control pills, certain HIV drugs (like indinavir), some cancer medications (like irinotecan), as well as Oxycodone (pain killer), Digoxin (heart medication), and warfarin (anticoagulant). It can also increase your sensitivity to sunlight if you're on certain antibiotics, such as fluoroquinolone, tetracycline, or sulfa drugs. - Don't take St. John's Wort without talking to your doctor first. - 6Take goldenseal to treat diarrhea. Goldenseal contains berberine, an enzyme that's commonly referenced in Ayurvedic and Chinese medicine to help treat gastric issues. In addition to alleviating diarrhea, it can help treat stomach pain and swelling, peptic ulcers, hemorrhoids, and colitis. [[7]](#_note-7)X [Trustworthy Source](/wikiHow:Delivering-a-Trustworthy-Experience)PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health [Go to source](#) - Typical doses of goldenseal are .5 to 1 gram (0.018 to 0.035 oz) of the dried rhizome 3 times per day, or .3 to 1 millilitre (0.010 to 0.034 fl oz) of the liquid extract 3 times a day. [[8]](#_note-8)X Research source - Goldenseal can be poisonous in high doses. For liquid extract, don't take more than 0.4 fluid ounces (12 mL) per day. For powdered goldenseal root, limit your intake to 0.1 to 0.2 ounces (2.8 to 5.7 g) ounces per day. - Don't use goldenseal for more than 2 weeks. - Typical doses of goldenseal are .5 to 1 gram (0.018 to 0.035 oz) of the dried rhizome 3 times per day, or .3 to 1 millilitre (0.010 to 0.034 fl oz) of the liquid extract 3 times a day. - 7Promote overall well-being of mind and body with tulsi. Tulsi, also known as holy basil, is known as the "elixir of life" in Ayurveda. It is a potent adaptogen that can treat anxiety, cough, fever, diarrhea, asthma, arthritis, eye diseases, high blood pressure, indigestion, vomiting, back pain, and even malaria. [[9]](#_note-9)X [Trustworthy Source](/wikiHow:Delivering-a-Trustworthy-Experience)PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health [Go to source](#) - Drink up to 3 cups of tulsi tea per day or take up to 500 mg daily to reap the most benefits. Use it up to 6 weeks at a time. - Avoid tulsi if you're pregnant, as it can cause your uterus to contract. - Tulsi may decrease the efficacy of anticoagulants like aspirin, warfarin, clopidogrel, and other antiplatelet drugs. - 8Drink chamomile tea to relieve insomnia. Sipping a cup of chamomile tea before bedtime can help you fall asleep faster and improve the quality of your sleep. Drink 1 to 4 cups daily or take up to 200 to 1,600 mg per day in capsule form. [[10]](#_note-10)X [Trustworthy Source](/wikiHow:Delivering-a-Trustworthy-Experience)PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health [Go to source](#) Advertisement - Chamomile is also thought to have anti-cancer properties. - Talk to your doctor before adding chamomile supplements to your treatment plan. Cooking with Medicinal Plants - 1Cook with garlic to lower cholesterol and blood pressure. Garlic is not only a delicious addition to your meals, it can reduce LDL cholesterol levels when you eat it regularly. Raw garlic bulbs have higher concentrations of allicin (a sulfuric compound) than tablets, capsules, or dry powders, so it's best to have it fresh. Add it to stir-fries, soups, sauces, or anything that could use a zippy, pungent flavor! [[11]](#_note-11)X [Trustworthy Source](/wikiHow:Delivering-a-Trustworthy-Experience)PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health [Go to source](#) - Raw garlic tastes slightly spicy and may cause nausea in high doses. The recommended intake is 1 to 2 cloves of raw garlic per day. For dried garlic powder, use up to 7.2 grams per day. - Garlic might reduce the efficacy of blood thinners like warfarin or aspirin. - Note that garlic is not a magic bullet—you still need to exercise daily and eat a balanced diet of whole foods in order to lower your cholesterol levels. - 2Add ginger root to various dishes to ease nausea and upset stomach. Ginger is best known for its power to relieve nausea and vomiting. The anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties are thought to disrupt serotonin receptors in your gut that cause nausea. It's also known to have positive effects on arthritis, immunity, colic, and heart problems. [[12]](#_note-12)X [Trustworthy Source](/wikiHow:Delivering-a-Trustworthy-Experience)PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health [Go to source](#) - Eat up to 3 to 4 g of ginger per day—that's about 2 tsp of ground ginger or 1 to 2 tsp of fresh grated ginger. - Use fresh grated ginger in various meals and accompaniments like stir-fries, meat and/or vegetable dishes, soups, dressings, and baked goods. It can taste spicy, so be careful! - Ginger may cause bloating, gas, and heartburn in some people. - If you have diabetes, be aware that ginger might increase your insulin levels and lower your blood sugar. - 3Add turmeric to a variety of dishes to treat arthritis and inflammation. Turmeric has long been recognized to aid in the treatment of oxidative and inflammatory conditions, metabolic syndrome, arthritis, anxiety, and high cholesterol. It has also been shown to relieve symptoms of depression and arthritis and lower your risk of developing heart disease, Alzheimer's, and cancer. Add 1 tsp (4.2 g) of turmeric to stir-fries, sauces, meat rubs, and vegetable dishes. [[13]](#_note-13)X [Trustworthy Source](/wikiHow:Delivering-a-Trustworthy-Experience)PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health [Go to source](#) - A single teaspoon of turmeric is equal to 200 mg. You can take up to 1,000 mg of turmeric a day for anti-inflammatory effects. - You have a low risk of developing side effects from eating turmeric. However, some people have experienced an upset stomach, nausea, dizziness, and diarrhea from taking high doses. - 4Use oregano to treat respiratory issues. Oregano can behave like an expectorant, helping you cough up mucus that might be causing a stuffy nose, headaches, and a range of other uncomfortable symptoms. Its antibacterial, antioxidant, and anti-inflammatory properties will help ease uncomfortable symptoms of the cold or flu. [[14]](#_note-14)X Research source Advertisement - Add fresh oregano leaves to soups, stews, stir-fries, sauces, and meat/vegetable dishes. - You can even make your own cough medicine with fresh oregano leaves and olive oil. Applying Plants Topically - 1Massage with rosemary oil to soothe sore or aching muscles. Place 5 drops of rosemary essential oil, 5 drops of nutmeg oil, and 5 drops of lavender oil into a small bottle with a cap. Then add in 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of coconut oil, place the cap on the bottle, and shake it up for about 20 to 30 seconds or until all the ingredients are incorporated. [[15]](#_note-15)X [Trustworthy Source](/wikiHow:Delivering-a-Trustworthy-Experience)PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health [Go to source](#) - Rub 1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) of the mixture onto aching muscles and painful joints and leave it on for at least 30 minutes. - As an alternative, mix 3 to 5 drops of rosemary essential oil with 3 to 5 drops of peppermint oil and 1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) of coconut oil. - 2Use mint leaf to clear up acne. Mint is rich in salicylic acid, which is typically found in acne medications. Simply crush or grind a bunch of mint leaves (at least 10) and add enough rose water (a few drops at a time) to make a paste. Rub the mixture on your face overnight to wake up to clearer skin. [[16]](#_note-16)X [Trustworthy Source](/wikiHow:Delivering-a-Trustworthy-Experience)PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health [Go to source](#) - Mint will also help treat oily skin. - 3Use aloe vera gel to treat irritated skin and prevent scarring. The gel of the aloe vera plant contains antiviral, antifungal, and anti-inflammatory properties. All those vitamins and antioxidants will soothe your skin and promote the growth of collagen. Extract the gel from fresh aloe vera leaves or purchase aloe vera gel from your local drugstore and smooth it on fresh wounds. [[17]](#_note-17)X [Trustworthy Source](/wikiHow:Delivering-a-Trustworthy-Experience)PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health [Go to source](#) - Keep in mind that aloe vera won't get rid of existing scars, but it will help prevent scarring from fresh wounds, including cuts, burns, and acne. - Don't apply aloe vera gel to open wounds—use it after the skin has closed up. - Aloe vera is also great for soothing pain and itchiness caused by sunburns and eczema. - You can also drink aloe vera water to help relieve constipation and symptoms of irritable bowel disease. - 4Treat psoriasis and other skin conditions with clary sage. Clary sage has antimicrobial, antifungal, and antioxidant properties that make it a great natural alternative to prescription creams and lotions. If you have psoriasis, eczema, acne, or dry, itchy skin, consider making a simple cream with clary sage oil. Mix together 6 drops of clary sage oil with 1 fluid ounce (30 mL) of coconut oil then rub it directly onto the affected area. [[18]](#_note-18)X [Trustworthy Source](/wikiHow:Delivering-a-Trustworthy-Experience)PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health [Go to source](#) Advertisement - Clary sage can also help prevent staph infections from cuts and scrapes. - Diffusing clary sage oil can also help ease menstrual cramps. Expert Q&A [Add New Question] [Submit] Tips - Use fresh plants and herbs as opposed to dried varieties. - For topical solutions, you can purchase plant-based essential oils online from a reputable website or at health stores. Warnings - Always talk to your doctor before taking any new supplements. - Talk to your doctor about any drug interactions that may occur from ingesting or applying certain plants and herbs. - Don't rely on plant-based medicines alone if you have serious health conditions (like cancer, liver disease, diabetes, or heart disease).
